reviews.review_text: I had the legendary edition previously and was holding out for BloodBowl 2. I was disappointed with what i saw and even more disappointed with the wave upon wave of issues Blood Bowl 2 has.   At 75% off I was convinced that I might as well finally opt for Chaos edition as I had always wanted to play chaos dwarfs anyway. Initially I was put off by 'made-up' new teams but the Khorne and Underworld teams add some variety that remains balanced in line with others.   Rest of the additions is simply more of what we had before.....  If you want to get into Blood Bowl then by far your best option is to ignore 2 and get Chaos edition of Blood Bowl 1. If you have either of other versions of Blood Bowl 1, then stick with what you've got unless you REALLY want to play one of the 3 new teams.  I loved Blood Bowl on tabletop and this version of the game is the best available! Highly recommended!

Rather than going for an re-interpretation of the Warhammer table-top game (Dawn of War), this game takes the Warhammer Fantasy football game 'Blood Bowl' and ports it perfectly onto PC. The game itself plays a lot like chess, with a turn based system in which one team attempts to score as many goals as possible (as you'd expect). The difference between Blood Bowl and an ordinary game of football, however, lies in the fact you can maim, bribe and murder the other team if you so desire, making for some intersting matches to say the least. The selection of teams is diverse, with each having their unique feel and playstyle instead of just being re-skins of the same team. If you're considering getting into the tabletop version, I most certainly recommend playing this first as it can teach you the basics of the game and is incredibly fun to play with friends.  Don't enable the real-time option if you value your sanity.

My old review for this was positive. And it technically still is. Blood Bowl is a great game. The underlying mechanics are great, and Chaos Edition was, even with the release of BB2, the definitive edition of the game.  Keyword was. With the release of BB2 we saw a slow downward spiral of the MP community, to the point where today, the only action going on in BB1, either CE or Legendary, is in scheduled organized leagues. As such I cannot reccomend BB1 to a new player. BB2 may be a steep ask what with the lesser amount of teams, but it's where most of the pickup MP community has gone. There also is the freeware alternative called FUMBBL, that's 2d and java based. Both are a far better option than BB1 now for actual MP.  Ordinarily I would not go an remove and change the thumb to a down for a game simply because of the MP community drying up, but for Blood Bowl the entirety of the game is both MP, and has moved on to a nearly identical platform as well at that, and thus I feel obliged to steer people to those two alternatives, either the updated retail version, or the smaller, more hardcore community of the freeware game.

Once you get past the dregs of online matchmaking and join one of the four or five very active communities with organised tourneys and leagues, blood bowl online becomes a very enjoyable experience. This is the edition that has everything and I heartily recommend it.  If you do play it, I recommend reading the rulebook (just google blood bowl rulebook). Although the game generally works very well, it's much more enjoyable when you sit yourself down to the actual rules. It's a little bit of work, but these rules were honed through years of playtesting and active experience and what has come out makes sure that every game is exciting, unpredictable and challenging. Above all it's a game that teaches one to learn to deal with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ situations you can be put in or marvel at the gutsy gambles that have paid off.  Not recommended for people that dislike chance as a whole; you can minimize the risk to a great amount and the winner of league is generally the better player, but the winner of a match is sometimes decided by the dice gods.  My very first game my most expensive player was hit and killed by a rock thrown by the audience; before I had even made a single decision. If that kind of thing sounds like fun, this game might be for you.

This is a pretty good game; it's rather an improvement to the first Blood Bowl.  If you've played the first Blood Bowl, you're in for no surprises, just some new teams.   The single-player portion is fun, but the AI is rather too easy to be useful practise for multiplayer.

I have never played Tabletop Bloodbowl so I will not compare the two.  Blood Bowl: Chaos Edition takes American Football, throws the rulebook out the window and adds in the Warhammer universe. All while your fate is decided with the roll of the dice..  This is like the ultimate luck simulator. Sometimes ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t plays work... sometimes they don't and you have the worst match in your life.  This is a good game to play with friends or in a small community. Public leagues are ok, but I feel you can have more fun with the first.  I throughly recommend this game. 8/10 Gabemas GabeN

Blood Bowl is a wonderful game filled with pain, suffering, and anguish for both your poor little meat bag pawns and yourself, as the dark god Nuffle makes your well thought out stategic plans crumble into ashen dust before your eyes as your freinds watch on, giggling at the shaudenfraidah like the cackling harpies they are! In all seriousness, blood bowl is a game of maximizing your odds of success against an oh so cruel random number generator with a fairly deep and varried system of mechanics which simulates a hyper violent game of foot ball played out by a bunch of fantasy creatures.   Buyer beware though, this game's tutorial sucks ♥♥♥, and if you go into this blind, you will be scratching your head as the game punishes you for blundering around with systems that you dont even know exist. Look up a tutorial or two on youtube and your expirance will be FAR more enjoyable than it otherwise would be.

I mean, the game is kinda fun, and when you start to get your team up there, its cool, but its just too unfair, which often means youll probably say screw this. ive lost my most valued player, with 6 Spp to a measly goblin with no spp, which means if you dont get lucky on the apothicary roll, that player is gone, if you dont reload the entire match and hope for something better.  play Dwarves, and you will win, they are unbelievably tough and though low agi, they get more lucky on agi rolls than Agi heavy teams  i dont recommend it, spite the fact i often play a match or two, because its way too unfair and too random in favor of the AI

It's Blood Bowl. What more needs to be said? It's Games Workshop's most balanced, entertaining and well thought-out game in their product history, and this is a faithful digital conversion.  There's a team that supports every possible play style, from brutal face-smashers and agile dodgers to thoughtful synergists.  You'll either hate this game within minutes of playing it (if you can't handle the element of chance and risk dice bring), or fall in love with it as you realise that it's all about minimising your own risk while maximising your opponent's.  If you've played TT BB, it's a no-brainer. If you've never played the table top but are a fan of turn-based strategy that requires real thought (and ultraviolence), then it's a must buy. Heartily recommended.

Mideval sports where killing is legal! That's one of many ways to describe Blood Bowl, a game that has you jumping for joy one minute and crying the next.  Based off the original board game, Blood Bowl is an American Football game mixed with chess-like strategy. You'll position players, throw blocks, and hopefully score touchdowns. Graphically BB doesn't offer much, you have a handful of stadiums and some customizable players, but where Blood Bowl really shines is its diverse character roster. 23 races fill BB stadiums, from the sleek Amazons, to the toughened Orcs, to the completely useless Halfling teams, each race works differently, and it's up to you to find which one fits your play style. For those who love destroying the enemy team, the minotaur teams of Chaos are for you, boasting strong players to help maim as many players as possible. Want to go around them, Skaven will do just fine. Wanna launch a hail mary, High Elf. However, keep in mind that each team has conflicting weakness that you must tailor your strategy to.  BB plays out kind of like chess and American Football wrapped in one. Two teams battle it out over 16 turns to score as many touchdowns as possible. This is where things get interesting. It takes a whle to get used to the rules and understand how everything works, but stick it out and you'll see the beauty. You'll see all kinds of strategies, like the typical punch everything style of Orcs to the outrageous physical game with Skaven, and you have to tailor your plan accordingly. Keep in mind that all the mechanics are dice based, like the original board game, so even though you baited the team and are set to make a perfect hand off, Nuffle (the BB God of the Dice) may say 'Nope!' and have him drop the ball, so no strategy is fool proof. When your not beating people/getting beaten sensless, you're buying players, leveling up players, and hiring cheerleaders and coaches. Blood Bowl's skill system is a lttle weird, having you roll dice. If you roll singles, you get to choose from a select few. Singles over a certain amount allow you to boost one of their skills. Doubles lets pick any skill or, if allowed, mutate, which gives you special abilities for certain races AND changes the corresponding character model, so expect to see a few Chaos Beastmen with tentacles, claws, or an extra head or arm.  The Verdict: +Fun Customization +Strategies for each race +23 races -Dice based combat system  8/10 Great  If you can get past the rules, find the right team, and accept that a few bad rolls are going to happen, then I sincerely recommend buy Blood Bowl.

This franchise finally peters out and dies a death. This expansion adds a Khorne team and maybe something else forgettble enough for me to have completely erased. Playing a Khorne team did not revive my attraction to the game, although the legendary addition I played historically is a great game that I played to exhaustion and enjoyed very much.   You'd imagine that having a BLOODTHIRSTER, one of the most terrifying creatures in the warhammer world, on your team would be a great basis for a team that wins on player injuries. I was underwhelmed. A Minotaur and chaos warriors from a vannila chaos team you don't need this expansion for are better at killing/disabling enemies -- and if a major demon and a bunch of bloodletters aren't going to deliver at least the same goods I have to wonder why this team is such a great addition.   Get the basic game, or if you have it already -- you can pass on this unless you draw satisfaction solely from franchise completion.

Best substitute for chess ever. It has violence. Orks. Chaos. Dark Elves. Ogres. Playing madden. It's all turn based and it has the exact same learning curve as the actual board game, but it's a very intelligent game as a result which requires good gambling skills.  The game's a bit aged now but still great fun to play, especially while waiting for the sequel (!) Blood Bowl II to come out. It's still active online too, at least at the moment of writing, and you want to be playing this game online to really learn it properly.  If you're looking for a game that challenges you to think and the idea of online chess where you can kill, foul and injure your opponents sounds interesting to you, give this game a chance. Just note that you need some patience, an average BB game against a human opponent typically lasts at least 1 hour.
Simple turn based chaos!
Bloodbowl is a tactical, turn-based, medieval-fantasy, sports game.  If you have to ask what that means, you'll never know.

I can't recommend this game enough. There are three major events that have scarred me forever that I think sum this game up:  1. My max level wood elf with AGI 6 and sure feet killing himself when going for it despite my team reroll.  2. Learning that Tackle was a thing when playing as the skaven.  3. Playing as Chaos and just trying to table my opponent.  This is the best turn-based sports simulator money can buy.

I really like this game, though I can't see it appealing to everyone. The strategy is actually pretty deep, though once you get a routine worked out for your team and the skills you want trained, you will play them about the same way every game. That said your opponents are many and varied and will keep you on your toes, not to mention there are a huge number of teams you can play.  On the down side it is a slow paced game and the UI is far from elegant. A match can take a good 30 minutes to an hour and there are lots of stretches of waiting for the game to set up the fields and the like. Still, if you don't mind life in the slow lane the level of detail and depth is rewarding.
Singleplayer feels very average. The multiplayer on the other hand is awesome. Tournaments are fun and people are generally friendly to noobs. I recommend buying this if you intend to play online.

I am a long time fan of BB and Games Workshop generally. The concept of BB and its universe is so rich that this should have been an amazing game BUT Cyanide got the licence to develop the game and, unfortunately, they butchered it, initially. Whilst the initial release of this game was horrible, after several years/patches/upgrades, it is now very enjoyable 7.5/10. The interface and UI are still terrible, but you will get used to it. And the graphics now look pretty dated compared to BB2, but dont let that put you off. This is an infinitely better game than BB2, which Cyanide is doing its best job to butcher, again.  Buy this if you like a bit of a tactical level up grind'fest. Dont buy this if you are a bad loser - the random number generated (RNG) dice rolls do feel somewhat 'rigged' against you sometimes.....
Heaps better then Blood Bowl 2, you can actually play a single player campaign mode with your own team instead of being given one not of your creating.
If you don't mind an element of randomness, this table-top gone PC game is lots of fun. Get some friends in on it for maximum enjoymentness.
Loved the board game and the PC version does a lot to make the game more accessible to more people.
